quiz.name: 2026 CFA Program LI Mock Exam 2 Session 2
quiz.subtopic: 2026 CFA Program LI Mock Exam 2 Session 2
instructions:
CFA Level 1 Mock Exam Instructions

This CFA Level I mock exam (Session 2) is in English and contains 90 multiple-choice questions. You will have 2 hours and 15 minutes to complete the exam and review your answers. 

Before You Begin

Please note the following in regards to this examination:

  • International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) apply unless otherwise noted.
  • "The Code" refers to the CFA Institute Code of Ethics.
  • "The Standards" refers to the CFA Institute Standards of Professional Conduct.
  • "GIPS® standards" refers to the Global Investment Performance Standards.

How to Answer Questions

  • Each question is numbered and includes multiple-choice options (lettered A, B, C).
  • For each question:
    • Decide which answer is best.
    • Select the corresponding letter.
    • Click 'Next' to move to the next question.
  • You may:
    • Select only one answer per question.
    • Skip questions or return to questions by selecting the ‘Previous’ or the ‘Next’ buttons.

After Completing the Exam

  • Click 'Submit' when you are finished.
  • Once submitted, you may review all questions and your selected answers.
  • Only selected responses will be scored.
  • Your score will reflect the number of correct answers only.
    • No penalty for incorrect answers.
    • It is to your advantage to answer every question, even if you are unsure of the correct answer.
  • If you finish early, use the remaining time to review questions you are unsure about.

Click the 'Begin' button when you are ready to start the mock exam.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Derivs-Agarwal-08
entry.itemBody: The price of a European call option is:

answerFeedback.0f3391b2-0e04-4089-8051-2b167a15a1f3: Correct because the value of a European call is directly related to the volatility of the underlying, and a European call option is worth less the more benefits that are paid by the underlying and worth more the more costs that are incurred in holding the underlying. Both relations are correct.
answerFeedback.14c275a6-9843-42b9-bf6b-3885d2378ec4: Incorrect because the value of a European call option is directly related to the value of the underlying, and a European call option is worth less the more benefits that are paid by the underlying and worth more the more costs that are incurred in holding the underlying. Therefore, both relations are incorrect.
answerFeedback.a54ec9ae-6dcd-42fd-95ef-2df7eebe2a13: Incorrect because the value of a European call option is directly related to the value of the underlying, but a European call is directly related to the volatility of the underlying. The first relation is correct but the second relation is incorrect.

choices.itemBody: A. directly related to the price of the underlying and inversely related to volatility of the underlying.
B. directly related to volatility of the underlying and inversely related to the dividend yield of the underlying.
C. directly related to the dividend yield of the underlying and inversely related to the price of the underlying.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-07474
entry.itemBody:
An analyst observes the following annual spot rates:

1 year 1.0%
2 years 1.1%
3 years 1.3%

Based only on this information, the arbitrage-free price of a 3% annual-pay bond with a three-year maturity is closest to:

answerFeedback.a5edf87d-0db5-4c6e-811c-89da6f264923:
Correct because the general formula for calculating a bond price given the sequence of spot rates is: PV = PMT / (1 + Z1)1 + PMT / (1 + Z2)2 + … + (PMT + FV) / (1 + ZN)N. where

PV = present value, or price of the bond;

PMT = coupon payment per period; Zt = Spot rate, or zero coupon yield, or zero rate at time t;

FV = future value paid at maturity, or the par value of the bond;

N = number of evenly spaced periods to maturity

Using this formula the bond price is calculated as 3 / (1.01) + 3 / (1.011)2 + 103 / (1.013)3 = 104.99059, rounded to 104.99.
answerFeedback.b68f46fa-3af1-4587-9987-306d82f44119: Incorrect because the exponents are omitted when calculating the price of the bond: Bond price ≠ 3 / (1.01) + 3 / (1.011) + 103 / (1.013) = 107.61584, rounded to 107.62.
answerFeedback.ceb79279-d2d3-40d3-8f79-71add2fc0c9d: Incorrect because the bond price is calculated as one would if given forward rates, not spot rates: Bond price ≠ 3 / (1.01) + 3 / (1.01 × 1.011) + 103 / (1.01 × 1.011 × 1.013) = 105.48441, rounded to 105.48.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-PM-Huffman-01
entry.itemBody: With respect to an IPS, which of the following best describes an absolute risk objective for a client's portfolio?

answerFeedback.0237495a-a001-40be-9565-6fb005672b02: Incorrect because for risk relative to a benchmark, the measure could be tracking risk, or tracking error. Further, an expected tracking risk of 2% would imply a return within 4% of the index return approximately 95% of the time. Remember that tracking risk is stated as a one standard deviation measure.
answerFeedback.415f3c54-1ee6-45eb-825d-851a5d703550: Incorrect because maintaining cash is an IPS constraint, not a risk objective. Liquidity Requirements The IPS should state what the likely requirements are to withdraw funds from the portfolio. Examples for an individual investor would be outlays for covering healthcare payments or tuition fees. When the client does have such a requirement, the manager should allocate part of the portfolio to cover the liability. This part of the portfolio will be invested in assets that are liquid—that is, easily converted to cash—and have low risk when the liquidity need is actually present.
answerFeedback.d054d5d2-dfd8-4d63-b243-61ff01f0ce9d: Correct because measures of absolute risk include the variance or standard deviation of returns and value at risk. For example, the 12-month 95% value at risk of the portfolio must be no more than ¥1 billion.

choices.itemBody: A. An annual tracking risk of less than 2 percent
B. A twelve-month 95% value at risk of less than €1,000,000
C. Maintaining at least €10,000 in cash for planned monthly withdrawals

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-05926
entry.itemBody: The average life of a mortgage pass-through security is two years. Six months ago, its average life was five years. Over the last six months, investors in the security have most likely experienced:

answerFeedback.27d0365d-3c35-4632-9513-35c0be9569cc: Incorrect because many commercial loans backing CMBS are balloon loans that require a substantial principal repayment at maturity of the loan. The risk that a borrower will not be able to make the balloon payment is called balloon risk. Balloon risk is not relevant to mortgage pass-through securities and in any case, balloon risk is a type of extension risk not contraction risk.
answerFeedback.77e2dc6c-5717-43ca-b5c7-b495ee596550: Incorrect because the average life extends when the prepayment rate goes down. In this case six months have passed but rather than increasing or staying the same, the average life of the security has decreased and decreased by more than the six month passage of time. Extension risk is the risk that when interest rates rise, prepayments will be lower than forecasted. As a result, a security backed by mortgages will typically have a longer maturity than was anticipated at the time of purchase not shorter.
answerFeedback.fdead068-cf12-4add-8ecd-5e72c0719014: Correct because the average life indicates to investors how long they can expect to hold the MBS before it is paid off assuming interest rates stay at current levels and, thus, expected prepayments are realized. The average life contracts rapidly as the prepayment rate goes up. While six months have passed, the average life of the security has decreased by three years. The relevant risk here is therefore contractions risk which is the risk that when interest rates decline, actual prepayments will be higher than forecasted. Thus, a security backed by mortgages will have a shorter maturity than was anticipated at the time of purchase.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-FRA-Hill-14
entry.itemBody: All else being equal, which of the following would lower a company's sustainable growth rate? A(n):

answerFeedback.6bc1cfb1-1b39-4ce9-84ac-d72f9b793358: Correct because the sustainable growth rate is the product of ROE times the retention rate, where ROE = ROA × financial leverage. A decreased ROA would lower ROE and therefore lower the sustainable growth rate.
answerFeedback.7dfa9752-b3ee-46dc-8972-8ad37203c537: Incorrect because the sustainable growth rate is the product of ROE times the retention rate, therefore an increase in the retention rate would increase the sustainable growth rate.
answerFeedback.b3d402e3-50ca-4bca-9cb6-126ee0d9e484: Incorrect because the sustainable growth rate is the product of ROE times the retention rate, where ROE = ROA × financial leverage. An increased financial leverage ratio would increase ROE and therefore increase the sustainable growth rate.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Alt-Shaw-06
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements about real estate investments is most accurate?

answerFeedback.1b1c53f5-e6c0-47e0-8857-cd2d3142d679: Correct because direct private investing involves purchasing a property and originating debt for one’s own account. Ownership can be free and clear, whereby the property title is transferred to the owner(s) unencumbered by any financing liens, such as from outstanding mortgages.
answerFeedback.345ec9bc-3b99-4aa9-a31f-7a088964ac7a: Incorrect because the main appeal of the REIT structure is the elimination of double corporate taxation. Corporations pay taxes on their income, from which they make dividend distribution to their owners from after-tax earnings. The shareholders, in turn, are taxed at their personal tax rate. REITs can avoid corporate income taxation by distributing dividends equal to 90%–100% of taxable net rental income.
answerFeedback.387a5ad7-7c3d-4d8a-95f0-64352c8224b3: Incorrect because alternative investment vehicles often take the form of partnerships in order to maximize flexibility in the investment structure to allocate business risk and return and to distribute special responsibilities between investors and managers as required. Limited partnerships involve at least one general partner (GP) with theoretically unlimited liability who is responsible for managing the fund. Limited partners (LPs) are outside investors who own a fractional interest in the partnership based on the amount of their initial investment and the terms set out in the partnership documentation.

choices.itemBody: A. Investors in real estate limited partnerships are exposed to unlimited liability
B. Free and clear ownership means that the property is unencumbered by a mortgage
C. REITs are required to retain most of their taxable income for future capital expenditures

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Derivs-Lin-11
entry.itemBody: In the binomial model, if the probability of a downward movement in an underlying increases, the value of a call option:

answerFeedback.4b6b21bd-c514-402c-b808-ea17cdb6a5af: Incorrect because, according to the binomial model, the value of call option is c0 = (πc1u + (1 – π)c1d)/(1 + r), where π = (1 + r – d)/(u – d).  Notably, the probabilities of the up and down moves, q and 1 – q, do not appear in the formula. Therefore, the value of a call option is independent of the probability of a downward movement in an underlying.
answerFeedback.51fe2a70-552a-47b9-90b0-1f84723b7027: Correct because, according to the binomial model, the value of call option, c0, is computed as the expected value of the option at expiration, c1u and c1d, discounted at the risk free rate.  This can be expressed as, c0 = (πc1u + (1 – π)c1d)/(1 + r), where π = (1 + r – d)/(u – d).  Notably, the probabilities of the up and down moves, q and 1 – q, do not appear in the formula. Therefore, the value of a call option is independent of the probability of a downward movement in an underlying.
answerFeedback.7e388a3d-9988-4ad7-a175-bebed05f800d: Incorrect because, according to the binomial model, the value of call option is c0 = (πc1u + (1 – π)c1d)/(1 + r), where π = (1 + r – d)/(u – d).  Notably, the probabilities of the up and down moves, q and 1 – q, do not appear in the formula. Therefore, the value of a call option is independent of the probability of a downward movement in an underlying.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-PM-Tsependa-06
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is best classified as financial risk?

answerFeedback.1c5b3423-f5d7-4b37-8cb5-f109dd534d8c: Incorrect because accounting risk is classified as non-financial risk. The following three non-financial risks are related: regulatory risk, accounting risk, and tax risk. They could even be collectively referred to as compliance risk because they all deal with the matter of conforming to policies, laws, rules, and regulations as set forth by governments and authoritative bodies, such as accounting governing boards.
answerFeedback.c00c9b54-9297-4a7c-befc-a3ef1e7b6c0c: Incorrect because closely related to health risk, and thus non-financial risk is mortality risk—the risk of dying relatively young—and longevity risk—the risk of outliving one’s financial resources.
answerFeedback.f50499b3-8ae3-424d-b56c-7c8258bb3131: Correct because the three primary types of financial risks are market risk, credit risk, and liquidity risk. Market risk is the risk that arises from movements in interest rates, stock prices, exchange rates, and commodity prices.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516102
entry.itemBody: For portfolio managers of active funds, market indexes are least useful as:

answerFeedback.1e627132-962c-48e0-99a4-a1dd4a463de5: Incorrect because market indexes are used as proxies to measure risk-adjusted performance of active funds.
answerFeedback.259c53cf-7d06-4345-b438-0b9ddd668b1d: Incorrect because market indexes are used as benchmarks to evaluate the relative performance of active funds.
answerFeedback.27d06a34-b3ad-429f-918c-dc585a7d1760: Correct because market indexes are used as model portfolios for index funds and exchange-traded funds, but they are not useful as model portfolios for active funds.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2023.01-Equity-Young-12
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is most likely an element of industry and competitive analysis?

answerFeedback.000d4d6d-e4a7-4d4b-9165-90ea2dad8482: Correct because industry and competitive analysis includes analyzing size, growth and character, profitability, and market share trends. It also includes analysis of industry structure and external influences, as well as evaluation of a company's competitive strategy and positioning.
answerFeedback.5ca4523d-79af-409b-b823-88fdd3e05ddd: Incorrect because analyzing uses of capital and sources of financing is company specific. Past and present company analysis includes analyzing capital investments and capital structure (uses of capital and sources of financing).
answerFeedback.f0993799-99df-4f05-8984-ac3881a0bb18: Incorrect because determining forecast objects and approaches is an element of forecasting in company analysis. The components of forecasting in company analysis include determining forecast objects and approaches.

choices.itemBody: C. Analyzing uses of capital and sources of financing

entry.title: ITEM_20170607065
entry.itemBody: Duration is most accurate as a measure of interest rate risk for a bond portfolio when the slope of the yield curve:

answerFeedback.407b6fd8-8da2-4b38-931b-db3932cb96ae: Incorrect because portfolio duration assumes the slope stays the same.
answerFeedback.5ebccbab-8051-4d4f-820d-50a1902f6285: Correct because duration and convexity for a portfolio are calculated as the weighted average of the statistics for the individual bonds. These measures of portfolio duration and convexity implicitly assume that yields of all maturities change by the same amount in the same direction, a parallel shift in the yield curve (i.e. the slope of the yield curve stays the same).
answerFeedback.d47bb88f-920a-45ae-8cba-b77c6369e1db: Incorrect because portfolio duration assumes the slope stays the same.

entry.title: ITEM_20170607024
entry.itemBody: Which of the following most likely exhibits negative convexity?

answerFeedback.953a3173-991e-4525-85b4-de872d3db5d1: Incorrect because a putable bond always exhibits positive convexity, higher than an option-free bond.
answerFeedback.991a4425-bff6-45de-8f96-07c03f978e71: Incorrect because an option-free bond always exhibits positive convexity.
answerFeedback.a54e9a3f-f510-4086-a780-41ea063027e7: Correct because a callable bond exhibits negative convexity at low yield levels and positive convexity at high yield levels.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B PM 03JRE
entry.itemBody: If a security’s return is plotted to the right of the market portfolio on the security market line, the security has a:

answerFeedback.2e73fbee-3a60-4d44-99aa-d52d7787b134: Incorrect because the SML demonstrates the relationship between a security’s return and systematic risk, not unsystematic risk.
answerFeedback.57c2fe19-eb85-4b32-8db5-4da8b1fd5786: Correct because the security market line (SML) is a graphical representation of the capital asset pricing model with beta, reflecting systematic risk, on the x-axis and expected return on the y-axis. The linear relationship between expected return and beta (systematic risk) is upward sloping. Therefore, a security that is plotted higher and to the right of the market portfolio exhibits higher expected return due to its exposure to higher systematic risk.
answerFeedback.eaf9777c-89ec-43f2-b46b-8d333df65f35: Incorrect because a security with a lower expected return and lower systematic risk would be plotted below and to the left of the market portfolio.

choices.itemBody: A. lower expected return and lower systematic risk than the market portfolio.
B. higher expected return and higher systematic risk than the market portfolio.
C. higher expected return and higher unsystematic risk than the market portfolio.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-PM-Tsependa-05
entry.itemBody: Emotional biases:

answerFeedback.1db3cbc0-dbf3-4a43-be4a-2a4fa908ed51: Correct because emotional biases stem from impulses and intuitions.
answerFeedback.846f178d-8faa-42fe-9155-e97036fa82ba: Incorrect because both forms of bias (cognitive and emotional) regardless of their source, may cause decisions to deviate from what is assumed by traditional finance theory.
answerFeedback.8f03b302-03cb-4c8d-9a5a-38541121381d: Incorrect because cognitive errors (not emotional biases) can often be corrected or eliminated through better information, education, and advice. Emotional biases, on the other hand, are harder to correct because they stem from impulses and intuitions.

choices.itemBody: B. result in the same decision as assumed by traditional finance theory.
C. are more easily corrected through better information than cognitive biases.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Alts-Mazararu-07
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is most advantageous to the general partner of a private equity fund assuming no clawback provision?

answerFeedback.2643b7e0-73df-4162-9094-e9f6308e1aad: Correct because there are two types of waterfalls: deal-by-deal (or American) waterfalls and whole-of-fund (or European) waterfalls. Deal-by-deal waterfalls are more advantageous to the GP because performance fees are collected on a per-deal basis, allowing the GP to get paid before LPs receive both their initial investment and their preferred rate of return (i.e., the hurdle rate) on the entire fund.
answerFeedback.91c92575-06fb-4818-962f-70daacd099df: Incorrect because there are two types of waterfalls: deal-by-deal (or American) waterfalls and whole-of-fund (or European) waterfalls. In contrast to deal-by-deal waterfalls, whole-of-fund waterfalls occur at the aggregate fund level (i.e., after all investments have been exited) and are more advantageous to the LPs.
answerFeedback.ca8ea635-d98a-4857-b3f6-7718aa68771c: Incorrect because whole-of-fund waterfalls -- which are another name for European waterfalls -- occur at the aggregate fund level and are more advantageous to the LPs.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-Equity-Tang-01
entry.itemBody: An investor buys a stock for $108 on margin by posting 40% of the initial stock price as equity. If the maintenance margin requirement for the position is 20%, a margin call first occurs when the price falls below:

answerFeedback.6ffa3152-7082-44a5-8e2b-44e2d578c0a4: Incorrect because this is the price 20% below the initial stock price ($108 × (1 – 20%) = $86.40) and not the level that triggers the margin call.
answerFeedback.90cfe537-a17a-4620-85a2-62b39ca847e4: Correct because the price below which a margin call will take place is calculated with the following equation: (Equity/share) / (Price/share) = ($43.20 + P – $108)/P = 20%, which can be solved for P = $81.00.
answerFeedback.e671b560-be54-4370-9dac-bf7143e72358: Incorrect because this is the stock price minus the initial margin requirement; $108 – ($108 × 40%) = $64.80.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.08-Deriv-Hambusch-09
entry.itemBody: Which of the following derivative contracts most likely requires an upfront payment by the buyer at contract initiation?

answerFeedback.625b64c2-89ec-4d04-a74d-65ea49cdc1d5: Incorrect because for forwards, at time t = 0, the counterparties do not exchange a payment upfront but, rather, agree on delivery of the underlying at time T for a forward price of F0(T).
answerFeedback.8fda878d-5bb1-4cb7-bcca-1504f8c6f1de: Correct because this right to exercise in the future has a value that is paid upfront to the option seller in the form of an option premium.
answerFeedback.f07bb187-e82e-4bd1-816b-d4e73e7ebe52: Incorrect because for a forward contract, at time t = 0, the counterparties do not exchange a payment upfront but, rather, agree on delivery of the underlying at time T for a forward price of F0(T).

entry.title: ITEM_Copy of 2019B Alt 04MTP 10U1
entry.itemBody: Making a minority equity investment in a mature company that plans to expand operations best describes:

answerFeedback.72f62e9a-0250-4054-9aa5-01a7f5d71202: Incorrect because leveraged buyouts (LBOs), or highly leveraged transactions, arise when private equity firms establish buyout funds (or LBO funds) to acquire public companies or established private companies, with a significant percentage of the purchase price financed through debt. In an LBO, the entire company is acquired, not a minority interest.
answerFeedback.b52b530d-b2ce-4382-b0b1-4933ab8197a5: Incorrect because venture capital (VC) entails investing in or providing financing to private companies with high growth potential. Typically these are start-ups or young companies, but venture capital can be injected at various stages, ranging from concept creation for a company to the point of a company’s IPO (initial public offering) launch or its acquisition by another company. Venture capital generally targets start-up or young private companies with high growth potential, not more mature companies.
answerFeedback.ca56a656-a47b-43cb-90b9-0c42129f8128: Correct because growth capital generally refers to minority equity investments, whereby the firm takes a less-than-controlling interest in more mature companies looking for capital to expand or restructure operations, enter new markets, or finance major acquisitions.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Derivs-Bangaruswamy-01
entry.itemBody: Arbitrage is best described as an opportunity to earn:

answerFeedback.55346bff-a80c-4aba-8f7f-c56b17352b58: Incorrect because an opportunity to profit at no risk could merely describe the purchase of a risk-free asset. Arbitrage is risk free and requires no capital because selling the overpriced asset produces the funds to buy the underpriced asset. Therefore, it is incorrect to state that arbitrage describes an opportunity to earn risk-free returns with large amounts of investment capital.
answerFeedback.99b74484-6823-4f45-87f0-a80aa803afd1: Correct because arbitrage is risk free and requires no capital because selling the overpriced asset produces the funds to buy the underpriced asset.
answerFeedback.ce9f7870-53b9-4854-87c1-4dcf20ad7fe4: Incorrect because an opportunity to earn a return in excess of the return appropriate for the risk assumed is a concept studied in portfolio management and is often referred to as an abnormal return. It is certainly desirable but is hardly an arbitrage because it requires the assumption of risk and the investment of capital. Also, arbitrage does not tell us the true fundamental value. It is not an absolute valuation methodology, such as the discounted cash flow equity valuation model. It is a relative valuation methodology. Therefore, it is incorrect to state that arbitrage describes an opportunity to earn abnormal returns applying absolute valuation methodology.

choices.itemBody: B. risk-free returns with large amounts of investment capital.
C. abnormal returns applying an absolute valuation methodology.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516171
entry.itemBody: Which of the following transactions is most likely to affect a company’s financial leverage ratio?

answerFeedback.ce6672e0-a794-448a-9b0e-3c4329f07a14: Incorrect because neither stock splits nor stock dividends affect a firm’s financial leverage ratio.
answerFeedback.d6012f05-bafc-465e-88c7-ad32c2c6c1e9: Incorrect because neither stock splits nor stock dividends affect a firm’s financial leverage ratio.
answerFeedback.f138abd7-529d-477c-8524-9c69f03fe026: Correct because cash dividends affect a company’s capital structure and financial leverage ratios by reducing assets and shareholders’ equity.

choices.itemBody: B. An increase in cash dividends paid
C. Completion of a previously announced 1-for-20 reverse stock split

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-07898
entry.itemBody: All else being equal, non-cumulative preference shares most likely:

answerFeedback.20a7a30d-9807-4d9b-9862-0fcc60ceb9d8: Incorrect because the requirement to pay past unpaid dividends applies specifically to cumulative preference shares, not preference shares in general.
answerFeedback.9e851c01-1b71-4ffa-8bf2-49c1cadf1486: Correct because preference shares rank above common shares with respect to the distribution of the company's net assets upon liquidation.
answerFeedback.b353254c-4b0a-4230-a313-3b9310f1aa73: Incorrect because the dividends on preference shares are generally higher than the dividends on common shares.

choices.itemBody: A. offer dividends that are less than common shares.
B. have a claim on net assets upon liquidation of the company.
C. receive any past unpaid dividends prior to dividends being paid to common shareholders.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606061
entry.itemBody: As one moves to the right along an investor’s efficient frontier, a set increase in risk is most likely to lead to:

answerFeedback.029015a7-ebca-4a71-a009-9fdefe42af3e: Incorrect because the slope of the efficient frontier continues to decrease, leading to smaller incremental returns, not larger.
answerFeedback.38765366-9347-4213-81f9-575713724444: Correct because the increase in return with every unit increase in risk keeps decreasing as one moves from left to right because the slope of the efficient frontier continues to decrease. Thus, investors obtain decreasing increases in returns as they assume more risk.
answerFeedback.ac6a0a05-6694-4ca2-8744-7819113879d0: Incorrect because the slope of the efficient frontier continues to decrease, leading to smaller incremental returns, not consistent.

choices.itemBody: A. sequentially smaller increases in expected return.
C. sequentially larger increases in expected return.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B PM 07SPH
entry.itemBody: Risk-averse investors make investment decisions that maximize:

answerFeedback.0d844eba-ebfe-4632-9d63-1feec52f31ab: Correct because risk-averse investors make investment decisions based on the risk–return trade-off, maximizing return for the same risk, and minimizing risk for the same return.
answerFeedback.1799071f-f535-4394-a277-1a2f45ec34b5: Incorrect because a risk-seeking investor would maximize both risk and return.
answerFeedback.758bdb5e-4891-49a3-8c4c-e76464f227dd: Incorrect because a risk-neutral investor would maximize return irrespective of risk.

choices.itemBody: C. return for the same amount of risk.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Leonida-02
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is most likely a factor that results in different credit ratings for debt issued by a subsidiary and debt issued by its parent company?

answerFeedback.45dcf1a2-4249-4682-8d2a-866dd3e99fc5: Incorrect because for the rating agencies, likelihood of default—default risk—is the primary factor in assigning their ratings. However, there are secondary factors as well. These factors include the priority of payment in the event of a default (e.g., secured versus senior unsecured versus subordinated) as well as potential loss severity in the event of default. Another factor considered by rating agencies is structural subordination. Recognizing these different payment priorities, and thus the potential for higher (or lower) loss severity in the event of default, the rating agencies have adopted a notching process whereby their credit ratings on issues can be moved up or down from the issuer rating, which is usually the rating applied to its senior unsecured debt. Therefore, differences between the issues' durations are most likely not a determining factor in the notching process followed by rating agencies.
answerFeedback.81b16551-f667-4be1-823a-9a59b6a9f5e6: Correct because structural subordination can arise when a corporation with a holding company structure has debt at both its parent holding company and operating subsidiaries. Debt at the operating subsidiaries will get serviced by the cash flow and assets of the subsidiaries before funds can be passed ('upstreamed') to the holding company to service debt at that level. Recognizing these different payment priorities, and thus the potential for higher (or lower) loss severity in the event of default, the rating agencies have adopted a notching process whereby their credit ratings on issues can be moved up or down from the issuer rating, which is usually the rating applied to its senior unsecured debt. Therefore, if the company's subsidiary is the operational entity that produces the cash flow and holds the assets within the holding company structure, the parent (holding) company itself will be structurally subordinated and will most likely have a lower credit rating than the subsidiary.
answerFeedback.f7311ad6-5656-4e72-9ed9-0aa96750a34f: Incorrect because cross-default provisions establish that events of default (such as non-payment of interest) on one bond trigger default on all outstanding debt, and imply the same default probability for all issues. For the rating agencies, likelihood of default—default risk—is the primary factor in assigning their ratings. However, there are secondary factors as well. These factors include the priority of payment in the event of a default (e.g., secured versus senior unsecured versus subordinated) as well as potential loss severity in the event of default.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-Equity-Crutu-10
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about an index with a starting value of 1,000:

Year Price Return Dividend Return
1 4% 2%
2 6% 3%

answerFeedback.96de0d1b-8f30-4c27-8e17-4140153d3348:
Incorrect because the calculation of the total return omits the dividend returns over the two years.

VTRIT = VTRI0 × (1 + PRI 1) × (1 + PRI 2) = 1,000 × (1 + 4%) × (1 + 6%) ≈ 1,102.
answerFeedback.ad28815e-592d-4e96-a1c0-c29ff5b10bd4:
Incorrect because the calculation adds all non compounded returns.

VTRIT = 1,000 × (1 + 4% + 2% + 6% + 3%) = 1,150.
answerFeedback.c172b6fe-274a-4ba1-bbf5-4f55e5c5e89b:
Correct because the value of the total return index at the end of Year 2 is calculated using the following formula:

VTRIT = VTRI0 × (1 + TRI 1) × (1 + TRI 2) = 1,000 × (1 + 4% + 2%) × (1 + 6% + 3%) ≈ 1,155.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-02009
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about three bonds:

Bond Payment Frequency Principal Amortization
1 Monthly Yes
2 Quarterly Yes
3 Monthly No

All else being equal, the bond with the greatest reinvestment risk is most likely:

answerFeedback.3fb78db9-44a2-4529-ac37-b5b299458cfd: Correct because the most common bond cash flow structure is that of a standard fixed-coupon bond, often referred to as a bullet bond. The bond issuer receives the principal at settlement, makes periodic, fixed coupon payments, and repays the principal at maturity. Reinvestment risk and price risk are types of interest rate risk and have an inverse relationship. Reinvestment risk is the risk of decreasing reinvestment returns on cash flows, which occurs when interest rates fall. Bond 1 amortizes principal on a monthly basis, which increases the reinvestment risk relative to Bond 2 (which pays less frequently) or Bond 3 (which does not amortize at all).
answerFeedback.90fb03be-f17b-4f13-ba47-3657c1324adb: Incorrect because Bond 3 has less reinvestment risk than Bond 1 or Bond 2 since Bond 3 does not amortize principal.
answerFeedback.c35ba35f-da66-4b78-8bda-4a6e42733f1e: Incorrect because Bond 2 has less reinvestment risk than Bond 1 because Bond 2 pays principal quarterly, rather than monthly.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06174
entry.itemBody: In an equally weighted portfolio of many assets, an increase in the correlation between the assets' returns most likely decreases the portfolio's:

answerFeedback.337fe7f4-5e56-44cf-957c-e59dd104d22a: Incorrect because the correlation between the returns of the assets in the portfolio does not affect the portfolio's expected return. Portfolio return = ∑wi × Ri, where wi are the weights of the assets in the portfolio and Ri are the returns of the assets in the portfolio. A change in the correlation of the assets' returns does not affect the portfolio return.
answerFeedback.e311305c-c4c0-4359-ada4-7db285f13516: Correct because sometimes a subset of assets will go up in value at the same time that another will go down in value. The fact that these may offset each other creates the potential diversification benefit we attribute to portfolios. However, an important issue is that the co-movement or correlation pattern of the securities' returns in the portfolio can change in a manner unfavorable to the investor. An increase in the correlation or co-movement of securities' returns adversely affects investors and reduces the diversification benefit.
answerFeedback.f7b2bf73-a936-446f-9d80-3023639d20fd: Incorrect because a portfolio offers a lower standard deviation of return than the average of its individual components due to the correlations or interactions between the individual securities. As correlation (covariance) increases, the variance of the portfolio (total risk) increases.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516137
entry.itemBody: Which of the following best describes an advantage of the EV/EBITDA multiple for valuing equity? An advantage is that:

answerFeedback.1ca9e4bf-8503-41a7-b4ef-31a29887b568: Correct because an advantage of EBITDA is that it is a proxy for operating cashflow because it excludes depreciation and amortization.
answerFeedback.8aa3ed55-0819-4d62-86ce-efdd5388b49a: Incorrect because the market value of debt is needed in valuing the equity since it should be deducted from the enterprise value and may be difficult to obtain.
answerFeedback.a5e9967b-7d80-4fcc-8b1d-497365591921: Incorrect because the multiple can be negative if EBITDA is negative.

choices.itemBody: B. EBITDA is a proxy for operating cash flow.
C. it does not require the market value of debt.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Derivs-Lin-05
entry.itemBody: The value of a swap contract at initiation is most likely equal to:

answerFeedback.8dd2f2d7-e847-4b1c-939b-9ac20ba51133: Incorrect because the value (not the price) of the swap is typically zero at initiation and the fixed swap price is typically determined such that the value of the swap will be zero at initiation. Therefore, the price of the swap should be set at a level so that the value of a swap is zero instead of equal to the value of the swap at initiation.
answerFeedback.b4682b8a-76dd-445a-8a2c-b10f9eabdca7: Incorrect because the principal of replication articulates that the valuation of a swap is the present value of all the net cash flow payments from the swap, not simply the present value of the fixed payments of the swap or the present value of the underlying at the end of the contract.
answerFeedback.db91875a-f518-4356-8edc-b6f09aef3053: Correct because the value (not the price) of the swap is typically zero at initiation and the fixed swap price is typically determined such that the value of the swap will be zero at initiation.

choices.itemBody: C. the present value of the fixed payments on the swap.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-01679
entry.itemBody: All else being equal, a cash dividend most likely has the same effect on shareholders' wealth as a:

answerFeedback.0269aea4-ee3b-4713-b6f4-8ae334cde593: Incorrect because stock splits and reverse stock splits are similar to stock (not cash) dividends in that they have no economic effect on the company or shareholders. A stock split involves an increase in the number of shares outstanding with a consequent decrease in share price.
answerFeedback.a8ebc559-388c-4d89-8bfd-8860dd18d1e9: Incorrect because stock splits and reverse stock splits are similar to stock (not cash) dividends in that they have no economic effect on the company or shareholders. A stock dividend involves an increase in the number of shares outstanding with a consequent decrease in share price.
answerFeedback.ad6fd56d-ec6b-4715-b11c-0b52399dea82: Correct because a share repurchase is viewed as equivalent to the payment of cash dividends of equal value in terms of the effect on shareholders' wealth, all other things being equal.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-03040
entry.itemBody: An arbitrage opportunity most likely exists if the price of a put option is less than the combined cost of:

answerFeedback.15d24801-fd58-46ed-b140-e71ef0c95215: Incorrect because the combination of shorting the underlying asset, buying the call, and shorting a risk-free bond at the present value of the exercise price does not equal a long put. Therefore, arbitrage opportunity does not exist even if the total cost of the above combination is different from the price of a put option.
answerFeedback.c801e3ab-aca8-440f-bd68-d041823de9d5: Correct because according to put–call parity, a long put is equal to a combination of buying the call, shorting the underlying asset and buying a risk-free bond at the present value of the exercise price. Therefore, arbitrage opportunity exists if the price of the put option is less than the combined cost of shorting the underlying asset, buying the call and buying a risk-free bond at the present value of the exercise price.
answerFeedback.cca86585-18b0-46b8-b267-417686c629d4: Incorrect because the combination of buying the underlying asset, buying the call and buying a risk-free bond at the present value of the exercise price does not equal a long put. Therefore, arbitrage opportunity does not exist even if the total cost of the above combination is different from the price of a put option.

choices.itemBody: A. buying the underlying asset, buying the call, and buying a risk-free bond at the present value of the exercise price.
B. shorting the underlying asset, buying the call, and buying a risk-free bond at the present value of the exercise price.
C. shorting the underlying asset, buying the call, and shorting a risk-free bond at the present value of the exercise price.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2023.01-Equity-Berlinicke-06
entry.itemBody: An analysis of the competitive positioning such as Porter's five forces is typically included in:

answerFeedback.0f678075-6c29-4045-bb94-4cbf34c09ff9: Correct because it is only part of the company research report element "Industry Overview & Competitive Positioning" which is not listed amongst the five elements for the subsequent company research report: 1.) Front Matter, 2.) Recommendation, 3.) Analysis of New Information, 4.) Valuation and 5.) Risks.
answerFeedback.6117a703-2b18-433d-b700-49d1d27365c2: Incorrect because it is typically only included in the initial company research report.
answerFeedback.96c7a4de-6e68-4c77-b675-80a06109bb15: Incorrect because it is typically only included in the initial company research report.

choices.itemBody: A. an initial company research report only.
B. a subsequent company research report only.
C. both initial and subsequent company research reports.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.06-Alt-Shaw-07
entry.itemBody: With respect to private equity funds, quartile rankings:

answerFeedback.4533a515-29e0-415f-8b9c-b480c951fe77: Correct because along this imperfect path and in an effort to benchmark how longer-term investments may be faring, private equity and real estate managers are generally judged by where they fall in terms of a quartile ranking, which depicts their performance against a cohort of peer investment vehicles constructed with similar investment attributes and funded around the same time, or what is often referred to as the same vintage year.
answerFeedback.e2d478da-a641-42e9-a2f0-4a2e1c0205c3: Incorrect because quartile rankings are commonly used in private equity and real estate. Along this imperfect path and in an effort to benchmark how longer-term investments may be faring, private equity and real estate managers are generally judged by where they fall in terms of a quartile ranking, which depicts their performance against a cohort of peer investment vehicles constructed with similar investment attributes and funded around the same time, or what is often referred to as the same vintage year.
answerFeedback.fd7c7f78-4e8d-4d08-8bfc-29787caac19f: Incorrect because quartile rankings are calculated for peer comparison with like, not different, investment strategies. Along this imperfect path and in an effort to benchmark how longer-term investments may be faring, private equity and real estate managers are generally judged by where they fall in terms of a quartile ranking, which depicts their performance against a cohort of peer investment vehicles constructed with similar investment attributes and funded around the same time, or what is often referred to as the same vintage year.

choices.itemBody: A. are rarely used for performance evaluation.
B. include comparisons of different investment strategies.
C. are based on funds launched in the same vintage year.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06492
entry.itemBody: In a semi-strong-form efficient market, which of the following is reflected in prices?

answerFeedback.a1a47303-d7ef-43d5-8470-4981e667f0fc: Correct because in a semi-strong-form efficient market, prices reflect all publicly known and available information. Publicly available information includes financial statement data (such as earnings, dividends, corporate investments, changes in management, etc.) and financial market data (such as closing prices, shares traded, etc.). Therefore, the semi-strong form of market efficiency encompasses the weak form. In the weak-form efficient market hypothesis, security prices fully reflect all past market data.
answerFeedback.c40c1504-ab8a-48ef-be15-daf39dff7e10: Incorrect because if markets are semi-strong efficient, no single investor has access to information that is not already available to other market participants, therefore private information is not reflected in market prices in a semi-strong-form market.
answerFeedback.eff9a3aa-f84f-4783-b179-99fc2ca77a8e: Incorrect because if markets are semi-strong efficient, no single investor has access to information that is not already available to other market participants, therefore private information is not reflected in market prices in a semi-strong-form market.

choices.itemBody: C. Both past market data and private information

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-03130
entry.itemBody: If a quarterly pay bond has an effective annual rate of 10%, the semiannual bond equivalent yield for this bond is closest to:

answerFeedback.0b251af6-9417-4558-b5ce-8883ff3a4bd1: Correct because the following formula converts an annual yield from one periodicity to another: 1+APRmmm=1+APRnnn. Here: 1+APR222=1+10%11,  1+APR22=1.10; APR22=1.0488-1; APR2=0.09762 rounded to 9.76%.
answerFeedback.82fade93-cc62-46de-95d9-6f3a36e8408e: Incorrect because it reverses the calculation as 1+APR211=1+10%22, and APR2 = 0.1025 = 10.25%.
answerFeedback.83afb44d-b46d-45c1-8ca5-0ec307d99604: Incorrect because it presumes 10% as an annual rate with a periodicity of four: 1+APR222=1+10%44, APR2=0.10125, rounded to 10.13%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-05108
entry.itemBody: Which of the following positions requires the investor to satisfy an obligation upon option exercise?

answerFeedback.43456de0-6dcd-4779-a434-c44a6147c31a: Incorrect because since the position is long, the investor has the right to exercise the option upon which the short side would be liable for delivery or, in other words, the short side would be required to satisfy the obligation.
answerFeedback.6dfd8fde-22bb-4400-b979-4ad7e08052e8: Incorrect because since the position is long, the investor has the right to exercise the option upon which the short side would be liable for delivery or, in other words, the short side would be required to satisfy the obligation.
answerFeedback.88400914-0f88-4aa0-920e-a4a082c3acdd: Correct because the long side of an option contract is the side that holds the right to exercise the option. The short side is the side that must satisfy the obligation.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516020
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements concerning a security market index is most accurate?

answerFeedback.76aafdd9-30ad-42f7-87c8-0d0e262f786a: Correct because an index provider will adjust the value of the divisor as necessary to avoid changes in the index value that are unrelated to changes in the prices of constituent securities.
answerFeedback.d5e6bb1b-b737-4a3e-bd0f-d0359a3055c4: Incorrect because at inception, the value of a total return index will be equal to the price index.
answerFeedback.ee4e3e90-ab6a-4a84-9029-9a28dcfc8e32: Incorrect because the value of an index is calculated using either the actual or estimated market prices of the individual securities.

choices.itemBody: A. Estimated market prices of constituent securities are not used to calculate the index value
B. The divisor will be adjusted to prevent changes not related to prices of constituent securities
C. At inception, the total return version of an index will be greater than the price version of an index

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.03-Deriv-Berlinicke-01
entry.itemBody: Which of the following best characterizes an interest rate swap?

answerFeedback.858253a2-977c-4d8b-a337-c0f8574c0acb: Incorrect because it characterizes an interest rate swap as a contingent claim rather than a firm commitment. Interest rate swaps are a type of firm commitment frequently used by market participants to convert from fixed to floating interest rate exposure over a certain period. And, specifically on the distinction between firm commitment and contingent claim: Firm commitments include forward contracts, futures contracts, and swaps involving a periodic exchange of cash flows. Another type of derivative is a contingent claim, in which one of the counterparties determines whether and when the trade will settle. An option is the primary contingent claim. Additionally, the second part of the answer is incorrect because survey-based Libor rates used as reference rates in the past have been replaced by rates based on a daily average of observed market transaction rates.
answerFeedback.da456561-1f85-4f36-bd12-c19a4d025750: Incorrect because it characterizes an interest rate swap as a contingent claim rather than a firm commitment. Interest rate swaps are a type of firm commitment frequently used by market participants to convert from fixed to floating interest rate exposure over a certain period. And, specifically on the distinction between firm commitment and contingent claim: Firm commitments include forward contracts, futures contracts, and swaps involving a periodic exchange of cash flows. Another type of derivative is a contingent claim, in which one of the counterparties determines whether and when the trade will settle. An option is the primary contingent claim.
answerFeedback.e1ba5079-42e1-4152-a55f-d9ba1cf3ed60: Correct because interest rate swaps are a type of firm commitment frequently used by market participants to convert from fixed to floating interest rate exposure over a certain period. For example, an investment manager can use interest rate swaps to increase or reduce portfolio duration without trading bonds.

choices.itemBody: A. A contingent claim derivative using Libor rates as reference rates
B. A contingent claim derivative used to convert interest rate exposure from fixed-rate to floating-rate
C. A firm commitment derivative used by investment managers to change portfolio duration without trading bonds

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-03860
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is best classified as a nonsystematic risk?

answerFeedback.16790e1d-24ac-4ba0-b015-6186fd9dbbcd: Correct because nonsystematic risk is risk that is local or limited to a particular asset or industry that need not affect assets outside of that asset class. Examples of nonsystematic risk could include the failure of a drug trial, major oil discoveries, or an airliner crash. All these events will directly affect their respective companies and possibly industries, but have no effect on assets that are far removed from these industries. Investors are capable of avoiding nonsystematic risk through diversification by forming a portfolio of assets that are not highly correlated with one another. A major auto producer failure will impact the auto industry but the impact can be mitigated through portfolio diversification.
answerFeedback.2188a06d-1a69-4154-b127-334cc8f782a3: Incorrect because systematic risk is risk that cannot be avoided and is inherent in the overall market. It is non-diversifiable because it includes risk factors that are innate within the market and affect the market as a whole. Examples of factors that constitute systematic risk include interest rates, inflation, economic cycles, political uncertainty, and widespread natural disasters.
answerFeedback.bd738aa4-c5d6-424f-abe3-0d9ad02e8cf1: Incorrect because systematic risk is risk that cannot be avoided and is inherent in the overall market. It is non-diversifiable because it includes risk factors that are innate within the market and affect the market as a whole. Examples of factors that constitute systematic risk include interest rates, inflation, economic cycles, political uncertainty, and widespread natural disasters.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-01874
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a company's preferred shares:

Par value $100.00
Annual dividend per share $6.00
Current market price $85.71
Maturity 10 years

If the required rate of return is 7% and the company's marginal tax rate is 30%, the preferred shares are most likely:

answerFeedback.364f7bb2-4fc6-4150-bbf9-c2d1482c0aaa:
Correct because 

V0 =∑t=1nDt1+rt+F(1+r)n

D = $6

F = $100

n = 10

r = 7%

V0 = $92.98

Given the market price of the preferred shares is $85.71 and the intrinsic value is $92.98, the preferred shares are undervalued.
answerFeedback.76e1644b-223d-4299-a45d-a9032e1687fe:
Incorrect because the formula for perpetual preferred shares is used instead:

V0 =D0r

D0 = $6

r = 7%

V0 = $85.71 which equals the current market price and implies the preferred shares are fairly valued.
answerFeedback.cfeba44f-f1db-4619-b43a-4f3f683e23b8:
Incorrect because the tax rate of 30% has been wrongly taken into account in the formula:

V0 =∑t=1nDt1+rt+F(1+r)n

D = $6 × (1 – 30%) = $4.2

F = $100

n = 10

r = 7%

V0 = $80.33

Given the market price of the preferred shares is $85.71 and the intrinsic value is $80.33, the preferred shares are overvalued.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-00911
entry.itemBody: Which of the following transactions poses the risk of losing the greatest dollar amount?

answerFeedback.c845754b-7f7d-4033-974d-b6a7386f850f: Incorrect because the largest dollar amount loss out of the three answer options is $14.10, which occurs for the case of selling a put with a strike price of $15 for $0.90. In the case of this response (buying a put with a strike price of $37.50 for $12.75), the profit to the put buyer is equal to Π = Max(0,X – ST) – p0. The put buyer has a limited loss, with a maximum loss occurring when ST ≥ X, in which case the profit is –p0, which is a loss of p0. Therefore, the maximum loss is p0 = 12.75, which is less than $14.10.
answerFeedback.cc1ed871-ea22-4933-b1a8-7cbe5370671b: Incorrect because the largest dollar amount loss out of the three answer options is $14.10, which occurs for the case of selling a put with a strike price of $15 for $0.90. In the case of this response (buying a call with a strike price of $15 for $11.25, the profit to the call buyer is Π = Max(0,ST – X) – c0, where c0 is the call price or premium paid by the call buyer. A call buyer is subject to limited loss and unlimited gains. The maximum loss occurs when ST ≤ X, in which case the profit is –c0 which is equal to a loss of c0. Therefore, the maximum loss is c0 = $11.25, which is less than $14.10.
answerFeedback.ed2c4f19-2c10-44fe-9567-269968d777ee: Correct because the largest dollar amount loss out of the three answer options occurs for the case of selling a put with a strike price of $15 for $0.90: The profit to the put seller is Π = –Max(0,X – ST) + p0, where X is the exercise price, ST is the price of the underlying at expiration, and p0 is the put price or premium. The put seller, like the insurer, has a limited gain and a loss that is larger the lower the value of the underlying. Therefore, the maximum loss to the put seller occurs when ST = 0, in which case the profit to the seller is –Max(0,$15 – 0) + $0.90 = –$15 + $0.90 = –$14.10 which is equal to a loss of $14.10. This loss is greater than the loss of the other two responses.

choices.itemBody: A. Selling a put with a strike price of $15 for $0.90
B. Buying a call with a strike price of $15 for $11.25
C. Buying a put with a strike price of $37.50 for $12.75

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Young-13
entry.itemBody: When securitizing a corporation’s loans, a special purpose entity most likely:

answerFeedback.91052c86-83b6-45a7-991d-b6179f40d8f2: Correct because the SPE purchases the loans or receivables and uses them as collateral to issue the ABS.
answerFeedback.bc73fb32-1f85-4102-8ea2-813022697ca8: Incorrect because the seller of the collateral is sometimes called the depositor. The SPE purchases the loans or receivables and uses them as collateral to issue the ABS.
answerFeedback.e3e6b45e-0f86-4d81-8764-4969b15b9b7d: Incorrect because the SPE purchases the loans or receivables and uses them as collateral to issue the ABS.

choices.itemBody: B. sells the collateral underlying the corporation’s loans.
C. purchases the corporation’s loans to use as collateral.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-Equity-Chan-12
entry.itemBody: All else being equal, which of the following securities is the most risky for an investor?

answerFeedback.a9a334a1-d0e9-44b2-975e-f12dca7828f0:
Correct because callable common or preference shares are riskier than their non-callable counterparts because the issuer has the option to redeem the shares at a pre-determined
price.
answerFeedback.ce2a88a9-a96b-41d2-9f70-4984ff36fa97: Incorrect because putable preference shares are less risky than callable preference shares. For example, from an investor's point of view, putable common or preference shares are less risky than their callable or non-callable counterparts because they give the investor the option to sell the shares to the issuer at a pre-determined price.
answerFeedback.faa37eb3-0539-4869-9bfd-5bd7942c55cc: Incorrect because non-callable preference shares are less risky than callable preference shares.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516159
entry.itemBody: An investor analyzes the stock market of a specific country and discovers that the stock prices are very slow to reflect new information. The investor can best profit from this situation using a(n):

answerFeedback.0f50e905-0afc-4484-93a9-bb48e45e099e: Incorrect. An efficient market is a market in which asset prices reflect new information quickly. Conversely, an inefficient market reflects new information slowly. In a very inefficient market, as implied in this situation, opportunities may exist for active investment strategies (such as those employed by active funds) to achieve superior risk-adjusted returns despite higher costs as compared with passive investment strategies (such as those employed by equity index funds or passive funds).
answerFeedback.93e8f592-9b63-4bdd-9c93-96d449d60aea: Correct. In an efficient market, asset prices reflect new information quickly. Conversely, an inefficient market reflects new information slowly. In a very inefficient market, as implied in this situation, opportunities may exist for active investment strategies (such as those used by active funds) to achieve superior risk-adjusted returns as compared with passive investment strategies (such as those used by equity index funds or passive funds).
answerFeedback.fa71cc26-8472-4b7a-a259-6534f3d3e6fb: Incorrect. An efficient market is a market in which asset prices reflect new information quickly. Conversely, an inefficient market reflects new information slowly. In a very inefficient market, as implied in this situation, opportunities may exist for active investment strategies (such as those employed by active funds) to achieve superior risk-adjusted returns as compared with passive investment strategies (such as those employed by equity index funds or passive funds).

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Kassem-25
entry.itemBody: If a bond has a modified duration of 7.1 and convexity of 49.2, the percentage change in price for a 50 basis point increase in yield is closest to:

answerFeedback.ea505189-64c1-4239-824f-6e1d3716eca9: Incorrect because the %ΔPVFull ≈ (-AnnModDur × ΔYield) + (1/2 AnnConvexity × (ΔYield)2). This incorrect answer subtracts the convexity. Using the data provided, (–7.1 × 0.005) – (1/2 × 49.2 × (0.005)2 = –0.0355 –0.00062 = –0.03612  ≈ –0.0361  or –3.61%.
answerFeedback.f4f7a839-2c2e-4502-9798-e8d9c075b028: Correct because the %ΔPVFull ≈ (-AnnModDur × ΔYield) + (1/2 AnnConvexity × (ΔYield)2). Using the data provided, (– 7.1 × 0.005) + (1/2 × 49.2 × (0.005)2 = –0.0355 + 0.00062 =  –0.03488 ≈ –0.0349  or 3.49%.
answerFeedback.f8199c27-0736-4d88-988a-0696d1518b4a: Incorrect because the %ΔPVFull ≈ (-AnnModDur × ΔYield) + (1/2 AnnConvexity × (ΔYield)2). This incorrect answer multiplies the wrong side of the equation by 1/2 to be (-–7.1 × 0.005 × 1/2) +  49.2 × (0.005)2 = -–0.01775 + 0.00123 = –0.01652 or –1.65%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-05349
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a portfolio:

 

Security Standard Deviation Portfolio Weight
A 16% 60%
B 27% 40%

 

If the portfolio's standard deviation of returns is 20.4%, the correlation between the securities is closest to:

answerFeedback.0d0f9dc6-c4ee-464c-b52e-9d2f3ff622b4:
Incorrect because using a correlation of -1 to calculate standard deviation results in a standard deviation of 10.3%

 

0.602*0.162+0.402*0.272+2*0.60*0.40*-1*0.16*0.27 = 10.3%
answerFeedback.51d76194-3939-4328-a247-a5d4223476bc:
Incorrect because using a correlation of 0 to calculate standard deviation results in a standard deviation of 14.45%

 

0.602*0.162+0.402*0.272+2*0.60*0.40*0*0.16*0.27 = 14.45%
answerFeedback.b000c77d-9eed-4bea-9bb9-025cbfad8072:
Correct because using a correlation of 1 to calculate standard deviation results in a standard deviation of  20.4%

 

0.602*0.162+0.402*0.272+2*0.60*0.40*1*0.16*0.27 = 20.4%

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-02561
entry.itemBody: The capital asset pricing model (CAPM) is based on the assumption that investors are risk:

answerFeedback.62c334fc-720d-4e62-bab0-c42f8a7cd0be: Incorrect because the capital asset pricing model is based on the assumption that investors are risk-averse, utility-maximizing, rational individuals.
answerFeedback.ab973944-5354-4e6d-a958-de07182efac0: Correct because the capital asset pricing model is based on the assumption that investors are risk-averse, utility-maximizing, rational individuals.
answerFeedback.c76f9b3c-3a95-4c6d-8200-45b19c764424: Incorrect because the capital asset pricing model is based on the assumption that investors are risk-averse, utility-maximizing, rational individuals.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Moustra-12
entry.itemBody: A buy-and-hold investor purchases a fixed-rate bond at issuance and holds it until maturity. With respect to interest rate risk, this investor is exposed to:

answerFeedback.3b5d36b4-5d11-4ed6-8a6a-db40b0276ffc: Correct because coupon reinvestment risk matters more when the investor has a long-term horizon relative to the time-to-maturity of the bond. For instance, a buy-and-hold investor only has coupon reinvestment risk.
answerFeedback.87d3d741-f1ba-40e7-acff-ff878a1c55f8: Incorrect because coupon reinvestment risk matters more when the investor has a long-term horizon relative to the time-to-maturity of the bond. For instance, a buy-and-hold investor only has coupon reinvestment risk.
answerFeedback.8f8d770f-99f8-4deb-b3c0-6f8e9880fee8: Incorrect because market price risk matters more when the investor has a short-term horizon relative to the time-to-maturity. For example, an investor who sells the bond before the first coupon is received has only market price risk.

choices.itemBody: C. both market price risk and coupon reinvestment risk.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-Equity-Islam-10
entry.itemBody: The value effect anomaly:

answerFeedback.36246d98-1726-4813-aff9-8ede9aadf892: Correct because the value stock anomaly contradicts semi-strong market efficiency because all the information used to categorize stocks in this manner is publicly available.
answerFeedback.3e755908-1d04-4a1b-a17b-ea7b7f390ab4: Incorrect because the value stock anomaly refers to the studies that have shown that value stocks have consistently outperformed growth stocks over long periods of time.
answerFeedback.5e921fa4-bbb7-4589-ba6f-6201783bebfe: Incorrect because the anomalies are placed into categories because based on the research method that identified the anomaly. Time-series anomalies were identified using time series of data. Cross-sectional anomalies were identified based on analyzing a a cross section of companies that differ on some key characteristics. The value effect was found based on cross-sectional analysis.

choices.itemBody: B. was identified using time series of data only.
C. states that growth stocks have consistently outperformed value stocks.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-FI-Simsek-02
entry.itemBody: A bond's price sensitivity to a non-parallel shift in the benchmark yield curve is best measured by:

answerFeedback.b9e31785-8977-4696-9d1d-afda7405ab00: Incorrect because approximate modified duration is a yield duration statistic in that it measures interest rate risk in terms of a change in the bond’s own yield-to-maturity. It is a measure tied to an individual bond, not the benchmark yield curve. It also assumes a parallel shift in rates.
answerFeedback.cea189e6-353a-458b-a275-4b414c7a3f96: Incorrect because effective duration is a curve duration statistic in that it measures interest rate risk in terms of a parallel shift in the benchmark yield curve.
answerFeedback.d9d3b9c5-0485-4a82-93ab-01170752cdc4: Correct because key rate duration (or partial duration) is a measure of a bond’s sensitivity to a change in the benchmark yield curve at a specific maturity segment. In contrast to effective duration, key rate durations help identify 'shaping risk' for a bond—that is, a bond’s sensitivity to changes in the shape of the benchmark yield curve (e.g., the yield curve becoming steeper or flatter, i.e. a non-parallel shift as opposed to a parallel shift).

entry.title: ITEM_20170607121
entry.itemBody: Which of the following instruments is most likely to offer investors some protection against increases in the market interest rate?

answerFeedback.04a7a415-376d-48e0-b2a9-88c1c54def60: Incorrect because fixed-rate bonds will decline in value when the market interest rate increases. The price of a fixed-rate bond will change as the interest rate used to discount future cash flows changes. For any time-value-of-money calculation, a higher discount rate results in a lower present value for any fixed future cash flow and a lower discount rate results in a higher present value. Therefore, bond yields-to-maturity and prices move in opposite directions.
answerFeedback.533b5dc7-c92b-4983-9cd3-08f0a982e754: Incorrect because floating-rate tranches can also be structured as inverse floaters, where the interest paid changes in the opposite direction of the change in interest rates. They are used to hedge interest rate risk in portfolios. When market interest rates increase, the coupon rate on an inverse floating-rate note will fall.
answerFeedback.a719287c-f3c0-43f4-92ee-ec50b4768947: Correct because bonds with variable interest payments are called floating-rate notes (FRNs). Floating-rate notes will be less affected when market interest rates increase because the coupon rate varies directly with market interest rates and is reset at regular intervals.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-PM-Tang-02
entry.itemBody:
An investor gathers the following information about a portfolio and the risk-free asset:

Average portfolio return 8.50%
Portfolio standard deviation of returns 16.00%
Portfolio beta 1.10
Risk-free asset return 1.75%

The portfolio's Sharpe ratio is closest to:

answerFeedback.1be18ead-78f0-4970-a08b-073ba3cd0e02: Correct because the Sharpe ratio is determined by using the following equation: SR = (Rp – Rf)/σp = (8.50% – 1.75%)/16.00% = 0.4219 ≈ 0.42.
answerFeedback.3070c9b1-c8db-497b-a1de-b7a67d314dfd: Incorrect because it omits the risk-free rate from the calculation for the Sharpe ratio; (8.50% – 0%)/16.00% = 0.5313 ≈ 0.53.
answerFeedback.c4625f1a-403c-424f-b151-13a2c0a925b1: Incorrect because it is the Treynor ratio, not the Sharpe ratio, for the portfolio. Treynor ratio = (Rp – Rf)/βp = (8.50% – 1.75%)/1.10 = 0.0614 ≈ 0.06.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-03855
entry.itemBody: Which of the following types of investors most likely has a long-term investment time horizon and high liquidity needs?

answerFeedback.22333b40-0411-41db-974e-96138d5ad804: Incorrect because while endowments have a very long term investment time horizon, they generally have low liquidity needs.
answerFeedback.9727e0b4-a8e4-4cc2-b09f-cb67788ffe45: Correct because life insurance companies have a long term investment time horizon and high liquidity needs to meet claims.
answerFeedback.a8419c86-68ed-49d3-b22b-ede2af5e178d: Incorrect because while defined benefit pension plans have a very long term investment time horizon, they generally have low liquidity needs.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-03127
entry.itemBody: All else being equal, which of the following bonds most likely has the lowest price?

answerFeedback.0da0a5af-96b0-41f9-907e-72fb005e01ec: Incorrect, as because a put provision has value to the bondholders, the price of a putable bond will be higher than the price of an otherwise similar bond issued without the put provision. Similarly, the yield on a bond with a put provision will be lower than the yield on an otherwise similar non-putable bond. The lower yield compensates the issuer for the value of the put option to the investor.
answerFeedback.3f3f0cb5-fcac-483a-a56a-c95611c65a8a: Incorrect callable bonds have to offer a higher yield and sell at a lower price than otherwise similar non-callable bonds.
answerFeedback.4554435e-cb9c-4aea-862f-0b541ce911ae: Correct because callable bonds are advantageous to the issuer of the security. Put another way, the call option has value to the issuer. For this reason, callable bonds have to offer a higher yield and sell at a lower price than otherwise similar non-callable bonds.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Berlinicke-02
entry.itemBody: Using the rating scale from Standard & Poor's or Fitch, the lowest rating for an investment-grade bond is:

answerFeedback.002ef0de-9fdf-44d3-80f4-ef92338f9fef: Incorrect because bonds rated Baa3 or higher by Moody's and BBB– or higher by Standard & Poor's and Fitch are considered investment grade.
answerFeedback.cbe28b5b-10af-47e7-bee9-d8ad99513ea6: Correct because bonds rated Baa3 or higher by Moody's and BBB– or higher by Standard & Poor's and Fitch are considered investment grade.
answerFeedback.d9c21e64-7011-46e1-aee1-bea5c469e9e6: Incorrect because bonds rated Baa3 or higher by Moody's and BBB– or higher by Standard & Poor's and Fitch are considered investment grade.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06264
entry.itemBody: If a risk-free asset is added to a portfolio of risky assets, the highest achievable return for a given level of risk most likely:

answerFeedback.2a1c054b-54d0-4443-b90a-4e7bf3346a89: Correct because an investor's portfolio improves if a risk-free asset is added to the mix. In other words, a combination of the risk-free asset and a risky asset can result in a better risk–return trade-off than an investment in only one type of asset because the risk-free asset has zero correlation with the risky asset. A better risk–return trade-off means that the investor's highest achievable return for a given level of risk increases.
answerFeedback.925ddf7b-c5c5-48e2-8807-1b4efe7b3043: Incorrect because an investor's portfolio improves if a risk-free asset is added to the mix. In other words, a combination of the risk-free asset and a risky asset can result in a better risk–return trade-off than an investment in only one type of asset because the risk-free asset has zero correlation with the risky asset. A better risk–return trade-off means that the investor's highest achievable return for a given level of risk increases.
answerFeedback.aeb5563e-a675-4ef8-8f4d-19d88b080598: Incorrect because an investor's portfolio improves if a risk-free asset is added to the mix. In other words, a combination of the risk-free asset and a risky asset can result in a better risk–return trade-off than an investment in only one type of asset because the risk-free asset has zero correlation with the risky asset. A better risk–return trade-off means that the investor's highest achievable return for a given level of risk increases.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Deriv-Fang-09
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements best describes the relationship between the net costs of carry and the forward price?

answerFeedback.774c7995-a326-468b-a2b9-ded48d50e76d: Correct because if the costs exceed the benefits, the forward price would be higher because the forward contract avoids the costs at the expense of the lesser benefits.
answerFeedback.ab4ee67d-c48c-433c-899e-a482ad7b37bf: Incorrect because the formula adjusts the forward price downward when benefits exceed costs of carry. So the forward price would be lower, not higher, when the present value of benefits exceeds the present value of costs.
answerFeedback.d29e0eb3-56ae-4e9b-8416-6c6c07bca95e: Incorrect because if the costs exceed the benefits, the forward price would be higher because the forward contract avoids the costs at the expense of the lesser benefits.

choices.itemBody: A. If the costs of carry exceed the benefits, the forward price would be lower
B. If the costs of carry exceed the benefits, the forward price would be higher
C. If the benefits exceed the costs of carry, the forward price would be higher

entry.title: ITEM_20190530039
entry.itemBody: A European call option is in the money whenever the value of the underlying is:

answerFeedback.0adc2b1e-946e-412d-9860-cb3f45c7ef60: Correct because a European call option is in the money when the value of the underlying is greater than the exercise price of the option.
answerFeedback.96e31f8d-c757-45ac-b9a0-1c46e5d7b18a: Incorrect because a European call option is out of the money when the value of the underlying is less than the exercise price of the option.
answerFeedback.a0ef0039-4fdb-43af-8597-2e6156dcc165: Incorrect because a European call option is at the money when the value of the underlying is equal to the exercise price of the option.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Derivs-Lee-07
entry.itemBody: Compared to trading an underlying directly, trading a derivative on the underlying most likely involves:

answerFeedback.66db681c-a779-4475-b697-94bf3b5fb975: Incorrect because derivatives are widely used and involve a high degree of leverage, it is a given that they would be seen in a crash.
answerFeedback.7fec9c77-e912-4bb4-aa09-33ff5e346a10: Correct because derivatives have lower transaction costs than the underlying. The transaction costs of derivatives can be high relative to the value of the derivatives, but these costs are typically low relative to the value of the underlying.
answerFeedback.f0712d04-685b-40a3-b924-a27b974ffb25: Incorrect because derivative markets also typically have greater liquidity than the underlying spot markets, a result of the smaller amount of capital required to trade derivatives than to get the equivalent exposure directly in the underlying.

choices.itemBody: C. a larger amount of required capital.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Alts-Ng-06
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements about alternative investments' compensation structures is most accurate?

answerFeedback.1823a82c-7c40-494f-8862-bce1dd8a0c0f: Incorrect because performance fee (not a management fee) is earned only after the fund achieves a return known as a hurdle rate (not a high-water mark). The hurdle rate is a minimum rate of return, typically 8%, that the GP must exceed in order to earn the performance fee.
answerFeedback.38090728-e070-4d7f-9147-69adf9581c84: Correct because until the committed capital is fully drawn down and invested, the management fee for a private equity fund is based on committed capital, not invested capital.
answerFeedback.b5025b12-79af-49a3-830a-4f334decfc5c: Incorrect because it is a high-water mark (not a hurdle rate) that protects clients from paying twice for the same performance. The hurdle rate is a minimum rate of return, typically 8%, that the GP must exceed in order to earn the performance fee.

choices.itemBody: A. A hurdle rate protects clients from paying twice for the same performance
B. The management fee for a private equity fund is based on committed capital until fully drawn
C. The management fee is earned only after the fund achieves a return known as a high-water mark

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.03-Deriv-Augulyte-13
entry.itemBody: According to put–call forward parity, a long put is equal to:

answerFeedback.15226f0a-e6b4-4232-b9a1-9ce693ea4759: Incorrect because the put–call forward parity is equal to: F0(T)(1 + r)–T + p0 = c0 + X(1+ r)–T, thus  p0 = c0 + X(1+ r)–T - F0(T)(1 + r)–T , where  p0 is a put, c0 is a call, X(1+ r)–T is a risk free bond, F0(T)(1 + r)–T is a forward (in present values).
answerFeedback.627dfe20-14ef-4baa-8d46-5609152b434a: Incorrect because the put–call forward parity is equal to: F0(T)(1 + r)–T + p0 = c0 + X(1+ r)–T, thus  p0 = c0 + X(1+ r)–T - F0(T)(1 + r)–T , where  p0 is a put, c0 is a call, X(1+ r)–T is a risk free bond, F0(T)(1 + r)–T is a forward (in present values).
answerFeedback.9d8c0d0d-3c4f-494d-8d27-cc7b952af50e: Correct because the put–call forward parity is equal to: F0(T)(1 + r)–T + p0 = c0 + X(1+ r)–T, thus  p0 = c0 + X(1+ r)–T - F0(T)(1 + r)–T , where  p0 is a put, c0 is a call, X(1+ r)–T is a risk free bond, F0(T)(1 + r)–T is a forward (in present values).

choices.itemBody: A. a long call, a long risk-free bond and a long forward.
B. a long call, a long risk-free bond and a short forward.
C. a short call, a long risk-free bond and a short forward.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Equity-Milosevic-07
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a margin transaction:

Initial stock price $80
Leverage ratio 2.5

If the first margin call occurs at a stock price below $60, the maintenance margin is closest to:

answerFeedback.3364fff6-5e60-4abe-bace-025eb63c6af7:
Incorrect because Equity per share is incorrectly calculated with the wrong percentage of equity formula: (1 - 1 / leverage ratio) [as opposed to the correct calculation of: 1 / leverage ratio] = (1 - 1/2.5) = (1 - 0.4) = 0.6 or 60%.

Using 60% to calculate the Equity per share, the equity per share = 60% × $80 = $48 

Applying this incorrect percentage of equity [60%] into the formula for maintenance margin -Equity per sharePrice per share = Equity per share + P - initial stock priceP =  $48 + $60 - $80$60 = $28$60 = 46.7%.
answerFeedback.526412ad-f459-4033-826d-f22d8898576e:
Correct because the maintenance margin is solved using the following equation:

Equity per sharePrice per share = Equity per share + P - initial stock priceP = Maintenance margin in percentage terms. 

Where P is equal to the price below which a margin call will first take place. Here this is $60.

Equity per share = Percentage of equity ×Initial stock price, where the percentage of equity is equal to 1Leverage ratio = 12.5 = 0.4 or 40%. Therefore the Equity per share is equal to 0.4 × $80 = $32. Therefore the maintenance margin is $32 + $60 - $80$60 = $12$60 = 20%.
answerFeedback.93631169-a615-4f79-8c52-c7605f6ab546: Incorrect because this response is calculated by incorrectly using the initial stock price [$80] as opposed to P, the price below which a margin call will first take place [$60]. This calculation is as follows: $32 + $60 - $80$80 = $12$80 = 0.15 or 15%.

entry.title: ITEM_20170607020
entry.itemBody: An analyst uses a valuation model to estimate the value of an option-free bond at 92.733 to yield 11%. If the value is 94.474 for a 60 bps decrease in yield and 91.041 for a 60 bps increase in yield, the approximate modified duration of the bond is closest to:

answerFeedback.af261527-20f3-4343-8cd4-f2e88d003c9c:
Correct because the approximate modified duration of a bond is

ApproxModDur =  ((PV-) - (PV+))/2*(ΔYield)*(PV0)

where PV_, PV0, and PV+ are the values of the bond when the yield falls, under the current yield, and when the yield rises, respectively, and ΔYield is the size of the yield change. Therefore,

ApproxModDur = (94.474 - 91.041)/(2*0.0060*92.733) = 3.09
answerFeedback.e836ceed-4f5f-4c05-bca8-42f34872d7e2: Incorrect because it ignores the 2 in the denominator.

entry.title: ITEM_20170427028
entry.itemBody: A hedge fund that implements trades based on a top-down analysis of expected movements in economic variables most likely uses a(n):

answerFeedback.93f89030-1bff-4a75-b92a-6e0c27fcc669: Correct because macro strategies emphasize a top-down approach, and trades are made based on expected movements of economic variables.
answerFeedback.a38eb886-56fe-4e9c-b13d-968e877da6ce: Incorrect because relative value strategies focus on pricing discrepancies between related securities.
