answerFeedback.ab141f7a-737d-47e9-843e-befe6bb94d76: Incorrect because event-driven strategies focus on short-term events that are expected to affect individual companies. The approach is thus “bottom up.”

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-FI-Tyler-05
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about three bonds:

Bond Issuer Credit Rating Total Issuer Debt Outstanding
($ Billions)
1 B 1
2 BB 1
3 BB 30

All else being equal, the bond with the greatest market liquidity risk is most likely:

answerFeedback.043437bd-e000-4b1d-a77f-85b88aa42cb8: Incorrect because although the issuer of Bond 2 has the equal lowest amount of debt outstanding, it also has a higher credit rating relative to the issuer of Bond 1, of BB. A higher credit rating likely means that Bond 2 has less liquidity risk than Bond 1, all else being equal.
answerFeedback.390f6ebd-ac5c-4e3d-ab6b-6308c5d51fab: Correct because the two main issuer-specific factors that affect market liquidity risk are (1) the size of the issuer (that is, the amount of publicly traded debt an issuer has outstanding) and (2) the credit quality of the issuer. In general, the less debt an issuer has outstanding, the less frequently its debt trades, and thus the higher the market liquidity risk. And the lower the quality of the issuer, the higher the market liquidity risk. As the issuer of Bond 1 has the equal lowest amount of debt outstanding and also the lowest rating of B, this bond is most likely to have the greatest liquidity risk, all else being equal.
answerFeedback.a70fbd10-eba0-4c03-b703-6b5dabc9f42c: Incorrect because the issuer of Bond 3 has the equal highest credit rating and also the greatest amount of debt outstanding. A greater amount of debt outstanding likely means that, all else being equal, Bond 3 has less liquidity risk than Bond 2 and, therefore, less liquidity risk than Bond 1 as well.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-03302
entry.itemBody: Four years ago, a 5% coupon, annual-pay bond with a 10-year maturity was issued at par. If the current market discount rate is 7%, the price of the bond per 100 of par value is closest to:

answerFeedback.14552724-86df-4f6e-9fe2-99cea3811094:
Correct because the price four years after issuance is 90.47:

P0 = PMT1/(1+r) + … + PMTn/(1+r)n + FV/(1+r)n

where:  PV0= the current market price or present value of the bond; PMTt = the coupon payment in period t; r = the yield to maturity per period; n = the number of periods remaining to maturity; FV = the maturity value of the bond.

So:  P0 = 5/(1.07) + 5/(1.07)2 +…+ 105/(1.07)6 = 90.4669 ≈ 90.47.

Using HP12C financial calculator for six years to maturity, FV = 100, N = 6, I = 7, PMT = 5, the PV or price = 90.4669 ≈ 90.47.
answerFeedback.4e1f6b67-f18a-4a98-a41b-18df4983c677: Incorrect because the price is calculated for issuance six years ago (not four years), using annual coupons. Calculator inputs are changed to N = 4 for the remaining years to maturity, PMT = 5, I = 7. The price is 93.2256 ≈ 93.23. Also, if semi-annual coupons are used for 4 years to maturity, then N = 8, PMT = 2.5, I = 3.5. The price is 93.1260 ≈ 93.13 and is closest to the incorrect answer C.
answerFeedback.dd1653e3-6f05-4a7e-902d-8575d2664ff8: Incorrect because semi-annual coupons are used instead of annual coupons. Changing calculator inputs to N = 12, PMT = 2.5, I = 3.5, the price is 90.3367 ≈ 90.34.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10940
entry.itemBody: In an investment policy statement, which of the following investment constraints most likely outlines a client's preference for environmentally sustainable investments?

answerFeedback.6b64570e-ed21-4d44-b6a6-867b6471df66: Incorrect because the section about time horizon states the time horizon over which the investor is investing.
answerFeedback.7762b294-9557-4500-bc7e-76a25693c04a: Correct because the section on unique circumstances of the IPS should cover any other aspect of the client's circumstances that is not covered by other sections and that is likely to have a material impact on the composition of the portfolio. ESG considerations - such as a preference for environmentally sustainable investments - fall into this category.
answerFeedback.9fa36d16-8f12-40d9-a958-127ef0b78061: Incorrect because this section of the IPS should state any legal and regulatory restrictions that constrain how the portfolio is invested. The decision to pursue socially responsible investing does not need to be driven by legal and regulatory factors.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-05784
entry.itemBody: For an institutional investor, the investment committee's approach to appointing and reviewing investment managers for the portfolio is most likely set out during the:

answerFeedback.29c4a898-0964-415d-abd1-e35b0be5e0c6: Incorrect because only once the IPS has been compiled, the investment manager can construct a suitable portfolio. Strategic asset allocation is a traditional focus of the first steps in portfolio construction. The strategic asset allocation is stated in terms of percent allocations to asset classes.The process of formulating a strategic asset allocation is based on the IPS and capital market expectations.
answerFeedback.3b41a6fd-d352-4110-9fb5-7692aa58f680: Correct because in the case of an institution, such as a pension plan or university endowment, the IPS may set out the governance arrangements that apply to the investment funds. For example, this information could cover the investment committee's approach to appointing and reviewing investment managers for the portfolio, and the discretion that those managers have.
answerFeedback.41bc9a75-1ec4-4ea5-83fa-33318d686044: Incorrect because portfolio planning can be defined as a program developed in advance of constructing a portfolio that is expected to satisfy the client's investment objectives. The written document governing this process is the investment policy statement (IPS). In the case of an institution, such as a pension plan or university endowment, the IPS may set out the governance arrangements that apply to the investment funds. Next comes the portfolio construction process, including the first step of specifying a strategic asset allocation for the client.

choices.itemBody: C. preparation of the investment policy statement.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-05218
entry.itemBody: All else being equal, for option-free bonds, the percentage price change for a given yield change is most likely greater for a bond:

answerFeedback.45278380-8352-410d-a39a-594edb598c8a: Correct because the convexity effect states that for the same coupon rate and time-to-maturity, the percentage price change is greater (in absolute value, meaning without regard to the sign of the change) when the market discount rate goes down than when it goes up.
answerFeedback.64e24f4b-5ecb-42a0-b936-6164d25e9ff7: Incorrect because the maturity effect states that generally, for the same coupon rate, a longer-term bond has a greater percentage price change than a shorter-term bond when their market discount rates change by the same amount.
answerFeedback.87c2367e-4dda-438f-b16d-340570df9ebd: Incorrect because the coupon effect states that for the same time-to-maturity, a lower-coupon bond has a greater percentage price change than a higher-coupon bond when their market discount rates change by the same amount.

choices.itemBody: A. with a high coupon than for a bond with a low coupon.
B. with a short time-to-maturity than for a bond with a long time-to-maturity.
C. when the market discount rate goes down than when the market discount rate goes up.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-PM-Glover-02
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements is most accurate? Smart beta strategies:

answerFeedback.a8a06159-3100-4c52-89e2-887b3fdd3502: Incorrect because typically, smart beta strategies feature somewhat higher management fees and higher portfolio turnover (not lower) relative to passive market-cap weighted strategies.
answerFeedback.d7757cac-599b-4530-a359-a057244ceb0d: Correct because smart beta, involves the use of simple, transparent, rules-based strategies as a basis for investment.
answerFeedback.f3529018-8814-43a4-af69-75f9a6418365: Incorrect because asset managers are increasingly offering other strategies beyond traditional market-cap-weighted exposures. Some of these other strategies, commonly known as smart beta, are based on such factors as size, value, momentum, or dividend characteristics. As such, smart beta strategies seek abnormal return from factors other than the market beta, which measures the market-cap-weighted exposures. Moreover, a stock's performance does not necessarily have a one-to-one relationship with these additional factors (such that a higher exposure generates a higher abnormal return).

choices.itemBody: A. invest in high market beta stocks to generate an abnormal return.
B. use simple rules-based strategies as a basis for investment decisions.
C. typically have lower portfolio turnover than passive market-cap weighted strategies.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-Alt-Burke-02
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a hedge fund:

Beginning-of-year assets under management (AUM) £200,000,000
Management fee (based on end-of-year AUM before fees) 2%
Incentive fee 10%
Soft hurdle rate 5%
Annual return before fees 20%

If the incentive fee is calculated independently of the management fee, total fees for the year are:

answerFeedback.a983fd41-95e7-460c-8b7c-f4ef45f0d772:
Incorrect because the incentive fee has been calculated net of the management fee and not independently of the management fee. The calculation becomes:

Management fee = (200,000,000 × 1.20) × 0.02 = 4,800,000

Incentive fee = ((200,000,000 × 0.2) – 4,800,000) × 0.10 = 3,520,000

Total fees = 8,320,000.
answerFeedback.bd9fa946-ea0c-42b2-8b78-ccbcd35ed30d:
Incorrect because the hurdle rate was treated as a hard hurdle rate and not a soft hurdle rate. The calculation becomes:

Management fee = (200,000,000 × 1.20) × 0.02 = 4,800,000

Incentive fee = ((200,000,000 × (0.20 – 0.05)) × 0.10 = 3,000,000

Total fees = 7,800,000.
answerFeedback.cf1faa2f-9de8-4067-ae7a-7ce24353b81d:
Correct because the partnership agreement usually specifies that the performance fee is earned only after the fund achieves a return known as a hurdle rate. The hurdle rate is a minimum rate of return, typically 8%, that the GP must exceed in order to earn the performance fee. GPs typically receive 20% of the total profit of the private equity fund net of any hard hurdle rate, in which case the GP earns fees on annual returns in excess of the hurdle rate, or net of the soft hurdle rate, in which case the fee is calculated on the entire annual gross return as long as the set hurdle is exceeded. Accordingly, the fees are calculated as:

Management fee = (200,000,000 × 1.20) × 0.02 = 4,800,000

As the return before fees is higher than the soft hurdle rate, the incentive fee is:

Incentive fee = (200,000,000 × 0.2) × 0.10 = 4,000,000

Total fees = 8,800,000.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516042
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is most likely one of the main functions of the financial system?

answerFeedback.2243b3a4-e9ee-487a-99d7-c1d9fe47e0e2: Incorrect, because the financial system provides sufficient funding only to the most productive projects. An important function of the financial system is to direct resources away from wealth-diminishing projects.
answerFeedback.6e0e8d4d-7f88-465d-8d75-987825fe6807: Incorrect, because informational market efficiency is not a key function of the financial system, rather that of regulatory framework.
answerFeedback.b54e4383-0586-4911-8b16-91146cae2424: Correct, one of the main functions of the financial system is to determine the equilibrium interest rate, which is the only interest rate that would exist if all securities were equally risky, had equal terms, and were equally liquid.

choices.itemBody: B. Ensuring that markets are informationally efficient
C. Ensuring that all investment projects receive sufficient funding

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10461
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is most likely a distinction between futures and forward contracts? Futures contracts are:

answerFeedback.64a86ef2-a1a1-428e-8433-95a4dbdbdfdd: Incorrect because a negative correlation between futures prices and interest rates leads to the opposite interpretation, with forwards being more desirable than futures to the long position. The more desirable contract will tend to have the higher price.
answerFeedback.73644c7f-ada9-491f-85eb-ca00f6b5a961: Correct because futures contracts differ from forward contracts in that they have standard terms, are traded on a futures exchange, and are more heavily regulated, whereas forward contracts are typically private, customized transactions.
answerFeedback.be1be87e-4325-4020-afe5-14a1cbfe4772: Incorrect because futures contracts differ from forward contracts in that they have standard terms, are traded on a futures exchange, and are more heavily regulated, whereas forward contracts are typically private, customized transactions. Therefore, it is more likely that forwards would be customizable than future contracts.

choices.itemBody: C. more attractive than forwards for long positions when futures prices are negatively correlated to interest rates.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-Alt-Vervloet-02
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is most likely a long-term benefit of adding alternative investments to a portfolio of traditional investments?

answerFeedback.15e1c36e-f2cb-4f43-9296-f42e99aa549c: Incorrect because features that may distinguish alternative investments include the following: Illiquidity, long investment time horizons, and large capital outlays. Hence, adding alternative investments is likely decreasing the liquidity of the combined portfolio.
answerFeedback.4e1ba24a-b829-4502-9e4a-710008ca58da: Incorrect because features that may distinguish alternative investments include the following: Typically low correlation of returns with more traditional asset classes. Hence, adding alternative investments is likely decreasing the correlation with traditional asset returns.
answerFeedback.6edd9ba7-85de-48bd-b59e-161dcdf4640a: Correct because investors often consider alternative investments in pursuit of greater portfolio diversification and/or increased expected returns.

choices.itemBody: A. Enhanced liquidity of the combined portfolio
B. High correlation with traditional asset returns
C. Improved risk-return profile of the combined portfolio

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06439
entry.itemBody: In the event of a default, which of the following mortgage structures exposes a lender to the greatest risk of loss?

answerFeedback.091238ab-6f47-489b-ba56-60c09be1a8ac: Incorrect because in a recourse loan, the lender has a claim against the borrower for the shortfall between the amount of the outstanding mortgage balance and the proceeds received from the sale of the property. Moreover, in a fully amortizing loan, the sum of all the scheduled principal repayments during the mortgage's life is such that when the last mortgage payment is made, the loan is fully repaid. Therefore, a fully-amortizing, recourse loan exposes a lender to less risk than a balloon payment, non-recourse loan.
answerFeedback.63a47c67-ec1f-4905-8853-cbfe48bfe81b: Correct because in a recourse loan, the lender has a claim against the borrower for the shortfall between the amount of the outstanding mortgage balance and the proceeds received from the sale of the property. In a non-recourse loan, the lender does not have such a claim and thus can look only to the property to recover the outstanding mortgage balance. Moreover, in a fully amortizing loan, the sum of all the scheduled principal repayments during the mortgage's life is such that when the last mortgage payment is made, the loan is fully repaid. Whereas in a partially amortizing loan [i.e. a loan with a balloon payment], the sum of all the scheduled principal repayments is less than the amount borrowed. Therefore, a balloon payment, non-recourse loan exposes a lender to more risk than a fully-amortizing, recourse loan.
answerFeedback.fcc0519c-057c-4f18-ae09-12445a35bc1a: Incorrect because in a recourse loan, the lender has a claim against the borrower for the shortfall between the amount of the outstanding mortgage balance and the proceeds received from the sale of the property. In a non-recourse loan, the lender does not have such a claim and thus can look only to the property to recover the outstanding mortgage balance. Therefore, an interest-only, recourse loan exposes the lender to less risk than a balloon payment, non-recourse loan.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-Alt-Shaw-22
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements about infrastructure investing is most accurate? Infrastructure:

answerFeedback.0b721d0c-28c2-4fee-83bd-a3e800f5dab5: Incorrect because infrastructure is funded via a mix of debt and equity, and is thus typically levered. Debt financing for infrastructure projects can be both private debt and publicly traded debt.
answerFeedback.682c4162-2125-4401-aed8-9982506698f3: Incorrect because infrastructure investors expect the assets to primarily generate stable long-term cash flows that also adjust for economic growth and inflation. Infrastructure investments provide some protection for changes in GDP growth, and offer some protection against inflation.
answerFeedback.aa76ac8a-e7cf-49f5-9929-fdba0f4a8733: Correct because infrastructure investments are real, capital-intensive, and long-lived assets intended for public use.

choices.itemBody: B. assets are intended for public use.
C. cash flows typically have a negative correlation with inflation.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516148
entry.itemBody:
An investor uses the following data and Gordon’s constant growth dividend discount model to evaluate a company’s common stock. To estimate growth, she uses the average of the:

1. average value of the compounded annual dividend growth rate over the period of Year 1 to Year 6, and<

2. dividend payout ratio for Year 6.

Year Earnings per Share Dividend per Share Return on Equity
6 $3.20 $1.92 12%
5 $3.60 $1.85 17%
4 $2.44 $1.74 13%
3 $2.08 $1.62 15%
2 $2.76 $1.35 11%
1 $2.25 $1.25 9%

If her required return is 15%, the stock’s intrinsic value is closest to:

answerFeedback.adefc6dc-e184-4ae3-ad1d-44471501121f:
Correct because V0 = D1 / (r – g); First estimate the two growth rates.

Compound annual dividend growth rate over the period of Year 1 to Year 6 =

1.25 × (1 + g)5 = 1.92

g = 8.96% ≈ 9%

Sustainable growth rate for Year 6 using the dividend payout ratio:

b = earnings retention rate = (1 – Dividend payout ratio)

= [1 – (1.92 / 3.20)] = 0.40

g = b × ROE; g = 0.40 × 12% = 4.8%

Average of the two approaches = (9 + 4.8) / 2 = 6.90%

V0 = D1 / (r – g)

= (1.92 × 1.069) / (0.15 – 0.069)

= 2.05 / 0.081 = $25.31
answerFeedback.dac08ca9-0853-444f-9dca-33d9bf4a85b8:
Incorrect because it uses the payout ratio instead of the retention ratio in computing sustainable growth rate: g = 0.60 × 12% = 7.2%;

Average of the two approaches = (9 + 7.2)/2 = 8.1%;

V0 = D1/(r – g) = $1.92(1.081)/(0.15 – 0.081) = $2.08/0.069 = $30.14

entry.title: ITEM_20170607067
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is least likely a component of yield spread?

answerFeedback.279397c3-076c-408c-907b-5fde41b2a459: Correct. Building blocks of the yield curve are spread (risk premium) and a benchmark (risk-free rate of return). Expected inflation rate and expected real rate are components of the risk-free rate of return (i.e., the benchmark).
answerFeedback.72d996ab-bd6c-4572-89eb-0410f5387511: Incorrect because taxation is part of the yield spread providing the investor with compensation for the tax impact of holding a specific bond.
answerFeedback.c3c9308d-77d5-48f9-81b0-6b2eafb8952f: Incorrect because credit risk is part of the yield spread providing the investor with compensation for the credit risks of holding a specific bond.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-01023
entry.itemBody: The earnings multiplier for a stock increases with a decrease in the:

answerFeedback.0b17a618-247e-4543-a0ad-ad392f9eed8c: Incorrect because a decrease in the dividend growth rate will decrease the earnings multiplier because the denominator in the model is larger.
answerFeedback.7e3fded9-11b0-4a7e-96b9-ea2351410048: Correct because a decrease in the required rate of return means the denominator has decreased, which increases the earnings multiplier (P/E) based on the earnings multiplier model: P0/E1 = D1/E1 / (r – g).
answerFeedback.927ddbf7-b2f2-4fec-9fb7-9950288912ef: Incorrect because a decrease in the dividend payout ratio will decrease the earnings multiplier because the numerator is smaller.

choices.itemBody: C. estimated required rate of return on equity.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-FI-Georgiou-02
entry.itemBody: The most appropriate measure of interest rate risk for a bond to a parallel shift in the benchmark yield curve is:

answerFeedback.5f852c6c-1bce-4ff5-bc0f-57953997dd37: Incorrect because modified duration is a yield duration statistic. There are several types of bond duration. In general, these can be divided into yield duration and curve duration. Yield duration is the sensitivity of the bond price with respect to the bond’s own yield- to- maturity.
answerFeedback.78b1db69-d3d3-4306-8f1b-afecdf085b1c: Correct because there are several types of bond duration. In general, these can be divided into yield duration and curve duration. Yield duration is the sensitivity of the bond price with respect to the bond’s own yield-to-maturity. Curve duration is the sensitivity of the bond price (or more generally, the market value of a financial asset or liability) with respect to a benchmark yield curve. A curve duration statistic often used is effective duration.
answerFeedback.c9fe5cc1-e52f-405f-b83a-4d431efbc4ad: Incorrect because Macaulay duration is a yield duration statistic. Yield duration statistics used in fixed-income analysis include Macaulay duration, modified duration, money duration, and the price value of a basis point (PVBP). A curve duration statistic often used is effective duration.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606069
entry.itemBody: A successful portfolio risk budget will most likely:

answerFeedback.05c9e237-b938-42e0-85d0-fad73e4d00c2: Incorrect because a portfolio risk budgeting process using only a single simple risk measure can provide substantial benefits to the organization
answerFeedback.3e69193d-bf34-4cf9-9e1e-b0f6335d14cf: Correct because whether the risk budgeting process focuses explicitly on it or not, it should result in choosing assets based on their ability to add the best return for each unit of the risk budget they use. Although some risk budgeting processes consider multiple risk sources, even a process based on a single risk can provide substantial benefits to an organization. While risk budgeting focuses on allocating the portfolio’s risk tolerance to its best uses, this does not necessary define a portfolio that will beat passive benchmarks. Risk might be best budgeted to passive investments.
answerFeedback.b6df7cf4-e451-4f50-a214-5f729085ba16: Incorrect because risk budgeting need not result in active investment decisions; the superior sources of return per unit of risk might be passive investment vehicles.

choices.itemBody: A. be based on multiple sources of risk.
B. produce superior performance compared to passive investing.
C. lead to investment in assets with the highest return per unit of risk.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B Equity 02DTL
entry.itemBody: In an order-driven market, if the trade price is determined by the limit price of an order, the market most likely operates under the:

answerFeedback.99e1247b-af6c-42a3-a195-d07a26346468: Correct because under the discriminatory pricing rule the limit price of the order or quote that first arrived—the standing order—determines the trade price.
answerFeedback.eb73f51d-2f40-40ee-a599-13554f69b5f3: Incorrect because under the uniform pricing rule all trades execute at the same price. The market chooses the price that maximizes the total quantity traded.
answerFeedback.ffec3a07-f5bd-42ba-bc47-df56b8a6bd95: Incorrect because under the derivative pricing rule the price is derived from another market, typically at the midpoint of the best bid and ask quotes published by the exchange at which the security primarily trades.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-Gosnell-Clone 03 of CFA-L1-00096
entry.itemBody:
An investor sells a European put option with the following characteristics:

Put price 50
Exercise price 1,640

If the price of the underlying at expiration is 1,670, the profit for the seller is:

answerFeedback.79918766-3565-46a4-a683-d72588f10792: Incorrect because it represents the put price p0 less the difference between the exercise price X and the price of the underlying ST at expiration: 50 – (1,670 – 1,640) = 20. This would be the profit to the seller of a call option, Π = –Max(0,ST – X) + c0, with the same exercise price and the same selling price. By contrast, to the put seller, the profit is Π = –Max(0,X – ST) + p0. Therefore, Π = –Max(0,(1,640 – 1,670)) + 50 = 50.
answerFeedback.acf619d1-b5f9-402d-b722-1dfc9de9984a: Incorrect because it represents the payoff to the call buyer cT = Max(0,ST – X), where ST is the price of the underlying at expiration and X is the exercise price. Therefore, cT = Max(0,(1,670 – 1,640)) = 30. By contrast, to the put seller, the profit is Π = –Max(0,X – ST) + p0, where p0 is the put price. Therefore, Π = –Max(0,(1,640 – 1,670)) + 50 = 50.
answerFeedback.f0bf3056-c0aa-403e-89a0-f080a95c7379: Correct because to the put seller, the profit is Π = –Max(0,X – ST) + p0, where X is the exercise price, ST is the price of the underlying at expiration, and p0 is the put price. Therefore, Π = –Max(0,(1,640 – 1,670)) + 50 = 50.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Equity-Crutu-12
entry.itemBody: Validity instructions indicate:

answerFeedback.30c03b7c-dc68-4085-b25a-ddb9afd2eb89: Incorrect because validity instructions indicate when the order may be filled, while clearing instructions indicate how to arrange the final settlement of the trade if the order fills.
answerFeedback.8301f6c7-89b0-4471-b9fa-da7aa69d28ba: Incorrect because validity instructions indicate when the order may be filled, while execution instructions indicate how to fill the order.
answerFeedback.9bd1e67d-4005-4c6a-910b-9514014098c9: Correct because validity instructions indicate when the order may be filled.

choices.itemBody: B. when an order may be filled.
C. how to arrange final settlement of an order.

entry.title: ITEM_20170427031
entry.itemBody: When the forward price of a commodity exceeds the spot price, the commodity market is most likely in:

answerFeedback.75536b4b-0ed1-42d5-ad3a-524f640abd56: Incorrect because when the spot price is above the forward prices, there is backwardation not contango.
answerFeedback.7c1f4b61-958b-4a35-b439-7aa15f52779d: Incorrect because carry does not relate to the relationship between spot and forward prices. In the context of commodities, cost of carry is the opportunity cost of holding these assets, and mirrors the risk-free rate and the cost of storing, transporting, and insuring the commodity.
answerFeedback.a159fa79-dff7-4bb0-a777-3eeb832c7138: Correct because when the spot price is below the forward prices, there is contango.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2023.06-Alt-Hambusch-01
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is private debt funding used by companies that are in the seed stage of their life cycle?

answerFeedback.1847a80b-fc41-41a0-8b42-1bbfccb03b7a: Correct because venture debt is private debt funding that provides venture capital backing to start-up or early-stage companies that may be generating little or negative cash flow. Venture debt is applicable to companies that are in the seed life cycle stage.
answerFeedback.1fa0bb3c-bb11-42e7-ac59-ee346830bee1: Incorrect, because mezzanine financing is applicable to companies that are in the growth, maturity, or decline life cycle stage, but not in the seed life cycle stage.
answerFeedback.2896d8c9-92d3-48e5-bf5e-a8b5747fcd4c: Incorrect, because direct lending is applicable to companies that are in the growth, maturity, or decline life cycle stage, but not in the seed life cycle stage.

entry.title: ITEM_20180516053
entry.itemBody: For a fixed-rate bond, Macaulay duration is:

answerFeedback.2e975875-651c-4a6d-a569-31c28c45ee20: Incorrect because duration is inversely (not positively) related to the bond’s yield-to-maturity.
answerFeedback.57f5e6ad-3c30-48e3-83db-042d0cb7f034: Correct because Macaulay duration is inversely related to a bond’s yield-to-maturity. All else being equal, a higher yield-to-maturity reduces the weighted average time to receipt of the bond’s cash flows. This places more weight on near-term cash flows and less weight on more-distant cash flows, resulting in a lower duration.
answerFeedback.aedd0584-615c-4776-8aef-b38a20011f74: Incorrect because duration is inversely related (not unrelated) to the bond’s yield to maturity.

choices.itemBody: B. inversely related to the bond’s yield-to-maturity.
C. positively related to the bond’s yield-to-maturity.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-PM-Croitoru-14
entry.itemBody: With respect to portfolio construction, combining long-term capital market expectations with the objectives and constraints from the investment policy statement determines a portfolio's:

answerFeedback.9e125936-fe29-4527-abf1-ee972d98104e: Incorrect because apart from the exposures to systematic risk factors specified in the strategic asset allocation, the returns of an investment strategy depend on two other sources: tactical asset allocation and security selection. Tactical asset allocation is the decision to deliberately deviate from the policy exposures to systematic risk factors (i.e., the policy weights of asset classes) with the intent to add value based on forecasts of the near-term returns of those asset classes. Tactical asset allocation depends on near-term capital market expectations, not long-term ones.
answerFeedback.dc9116bf-6c0b-49cb-906b-a645ba420945: Correct because a strategic asset allocation results from combining the constraints and objectives articulated in the IPS and long-term capital market expectations regarding the asset classes. Capital market expectations are the investor’s expectations concerning the risk and return prospects of asset classes, however broadly or narrowly the investor defines those asset classes. When associated with the client’s investment objectives, the result is the strategic asset allocation that is expected to allow the client to achieve his or her investment objectives.
answerFeedback.fa5e6562-74af-48d2-99f1-c72f24386535: Incorrect because security selection is an attempt to generate higher returns than the asset class benchmark by selecting securities with a higher expected return. Risk budgeting implies that the portfolio manager has to choose, for every asset class, whether to deploy security selection as a return generator. This choice is generally referred to as the choice between active or passive management. Contrary to strategic asset allocation, where exposures to sources of systematic risk are selected and sized, security selection is not rewarded with a long-run payoff to risk. Security selection is a zero-sum game: All investors in an asset class are competing with each to identify a typically limited number of assets that are misvalued. Combining the objectives and constraints from the IPS with the long-term capital market expectations determines the strategic asset allocation.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2023.01-Alt-Berlinicke-06
entry.itemBody: The correlation of cryptocurrencies with traditional assets has been:

answerFeedback.69b08c6a-bbb6-4edd-8a0e-78fba73a3d2a: Correct because the correlation of cryptocurrencies with traditional assets is on the rise.
answerFeedback.c871c4ae-2462-4228-9c7d-048959c94636: Incorrect because the correlation of cryptocurrencies with traditional assets is on the rise.
answerFeedback.cfebaa3c-234e-4d84-b935-dd3ebb333312: Incorrect because the correlation of cryptocurrencies with traditional assets is on the rise.

entry.title: ITEM_20170427041
entry.itemBody:
Initial investment capital $100 million
Return at the end of one year 12%
Management fee based on assets under management 1%
Incentive fee based on the return net of the management fee 10%

Assume management fees are calculated using end-of-period valuation. The investor’s net return given this fee structure is closest to:

answerFeedback.6698f091-db45-438f-8a16-0e2427011e04:
Incorrect. It ignores the fact that the incentive fee is calculated net of management fees. Management fee: 1% of $112 million = $1.12 million.

Incentive fee: 10% of $12 million = $1.2 million.

Fund value after fees: $112 million – $1.12 million – $1.2 million = $109.68 million

Investor return: ($109.68 million / $100 million) - 1 = 9.68%
answerFeedback.779991f9-a572-491f-8721-4e6820c91602:
Incorrect. It neglects the incentive fee.

Management fee: 1% of $112 million = $1.12 million

Fund value after fees: $112 million – $1.12 million = $110.88 million

Investor return: ($110.88 million/$100 million) – 1 = 10.88%

Correct.

Management fee: 1% of $112 million = $1.12 million

Incentive fee: 10% of ($12 million – $ 1.12 million) = $1.088 million

Fund value after fees: $112 million – $1.12 million – $1.088 million = $109.792 million

Investor return: ($109.792 million/$100 million) – 1 = 9.79%
